snippet: A new push in the Senate has complicated efforts to pass a defense spending bill, threatening a piece of bipartisan legislation that needs approval before the end of the year.
abstract: Sen Kirsten E Gillibrand, Democrat of New York, is asking for a vote on a bill that would remove military commanders from overseeing sexual assault prosecutions in the armed forces; measure faces uphill battle from Pentagon and lawmakers who agree that change is needed, but breaking chain of command is wrong approach.

byline.original: By JEREMY W. PETERS and EMMARIE HUETTEMAN

lead_paragraph: A new push in the Senate has complicated efforts to pass a defense spending bill, threatening a piece of bipartisan legislation that needs approval before the end of the year.

headline.main: Gillibrand Seeks Another Vote on Military’s Handling of Sexual Assault Cases
headline.print_headline: Gillibrand Seeks Another Vote on Military’s Handling of Sexual Assault Cases

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject
